document_title: Spatially resolved multiomics on the neuronal effects induced by spaceflight in mice
summary_full: This study investigated the impact of spaceflight on the mouse brain using an integrated approach of single-cell multiomics (transcriptomics and chromatin accessibility) and spatial transcriptomics. Female mice exposed to spaceflight on the International Space Station showed significant alterations in neurogenesis, synaptogenesis, and synaptic transmission, particularly in the cortex, hippocampus, and striatum. The study also observed astrocyte activation, signs of immune dysfunction, and pathways resembling neurodegenerative disorders, including oxidative stress and protein misfolding. The findings highlight region-specific and cell-type-specific responses to spaceflight, providing a foundation for understanding CNS health risks in astronauts and for future space biology research. All datasets are publicly available.
key_findings: Spaceflight significantly alters neurogenesis, synaptogenesis, and synaptic transmission in multiple brain regions of mice, including the cortex, hippocampus, and striatum.
Astrocyte activation and signs of immune dysfunction were observed in spaceflight-exposed mice.
Spaceflight-induced brain changes share pathway similarities with neurodegenerative disorders, characterized by oxidative stress and protein misfolding.
Integrated spatial multiomics revealed region-specific and cell-type-specific responses to spaceflight.
Ligand-receptor interaction analysis suggests spaceflight-mediated effects on astrocyte functions, particularly involving EGFR and VEGFA.
Metabolic pathway analysis indicated spaceflight-mediated inhibition of oxidative phosphorylation and glycolysis.
future_research_fields: Investigating the persistence of spaceflight-induced CNS impairments after reacclimation to Earth.
Exploring sex-specific differences in CNS responses to spaceflight.
Developing and testing anti-aging and neuroprotective therapeutics as spaceflight countermeasures.
Utilizing spaceflight as a model for accelerated aging studies.
Further investigating neuroimmune outcomes and circadian rhythm dysregulation in spaceflight.
Comparing spaceflight effects using human CNS organoid models.
conclusions: Spaceflight induces significant molecular and cellular changes in the mouse brain, affecting neurogenesis, synaptogenesis, synaptic transmission, and metabolic pathways. These alterations bear resemblance to neurodegenerative conditions and aging, highlighting potential long-term health risks for astronauts. The study underscores the value of integrated multiomics and spatial transcriptomics for detailed CNS analysis in space biology research.
impact_statement: This study provides critical insights into the neurological effects of spaceflight, informing astronaut health and guiding the development of countermeasures for future long-duration space missions.
